node.contents: In this below example, say file.xml There are values inside tags return code=" " I need the values inside <Port name="write_qwe"> ONLY.

astNode.text: In this below example, say file.xml There are values inside tags return code=" " I need the values inside <Port name="write_qwe"> ONLY.

elements.contents: <Main display="NORMAL"> <Port name="read_abc" exe="NO"> <input> <struct file="C:\temp" sign="id1"/> </input> <output> <return code="33" shortmsg="Implementation not found for commande."/> </output> </Port> <Port name="write_qwe" exe="NO"> <input> <struct file="C:\temp" id="id1"/> </input> <output> <return code="1" shortmsg="NOTEXECUTED" longmsg="Not execute due to previous error"/> </output> </Port> <Port name="read_abc" exe="NO"> <input> <struct file="C:\temp" sign="id2"/> </input> <output> <return code="66" shortmsg="Implementation"/> </output> </Port> <Port name="write_qwe" exe="NO"> <input> <struct file="C:\temp" id="id2"/> </input> <output> <return code="0" shortmsg="NOTEXECUTED" /> </output> </Port> </Main>

units.rawText: <Main display="NORMAL"> <Port name="read_abc"exe="NO"> <input> <struct file="C:\temp"sign="id1"/> </input> <output> <return code="33"shortmsg="Implementation not found for commande."/> </output> </Port> <Port name="write_qwe"exe="NO"> <input> <struct file="C:\temp"id="id1"/> </input> <output> <return code="1"shortmsg="NOTEXECUTED"longmsg="Not execute due to previous error"/> </output> </Port> <Port name="read_abc"exe="NO"> <input> <struct file="C:\temp"sign="id2"/> </input> <output> <return code="66"shortmsg="Implementation"/> </output> </Port> <Port name="write_qwe"exe="NO"> <input> <struct file="C:\temp"id="id2"/> </input> <output> <return code="0"shortmsg="NOTEXECUTED"/> </output> </Port> </Main>

node.contents: I need to get the value of the <return code" "> which is inside <port name="write_*"> and inside <output> . In this example I need to get values "1" and "0" .

astNode.text: I need to get the value of the <return code" "> which is inside <port name="write_*"> and inside <output> . In this example I need to get values "1" and "0" .

node.contents: If you dont have any problem in using xpath ,then you can try this :

astNode.text: If you dont have any problem in using xpath ,then you can try this :

node.contents: You have to give the path of your xml file in the argument.

astNode.text: You have to give the path of your xml file in the argument.

elements.contents: XPathReader reader = new XPathReader("FileName.xml"); // To get a xml attribute. String expression = "/Main/Port/output/@code"; System.out.println(reader.read(expression,XPathConstants.STRING) + "n");

comments.text: // To get a xml attribute. String expression = "/Main/Port/output/@code"; System.out.println(reader.read(expression,XPathConstants.STRING) + "n");

units.rawText: XPathReader reader = new XPathReader("FileName.xml"); // To get a xml attribute. String expression = "/Main/Port/output/@code"; System.out.println(reader.read(expression,XPathConstants.STRING) + "n");

node.contents: if your XML is a String, Then you can do the following:

astNode.text: if your XML is a String, Then you can do the following:

elements.contents: String xml = ""; //Populated XML String.... DocumentBuilderFactory factory = DocumentBuilderFactory.newInstance(); DocumentBuilder builder = DocumentBuilderFactory.newDocumentBuilder(); Document document = builder.parse(new InputSource(new StringReader(xml))); Element rootElement = document.getDocumentElement();

comments.text: //Populated XML String.... DocumentBuilderFactory factory = DocumentBuilderFactory.newInstance(); DocumentBuilder builder = DocumentBuilderFactory.newDocumentBuilder(); Document document = builder.parse(new InputSource(new StringReader(xml))); Element rootElement = document.getDocumentElement();

units.rawText: String xml = ""; //Populated XML String.... DocumentBuilderFactory factory = DocumentBuilderFactory.newInstance(); DocumentBuilder builder = DocumentBuilderFactory.newDocumentBuilder(); Document document = builder.parse(new InputSource(new StringReader(xml))); Element rootElement = document.getDocumentElement();

node.contents: If your XML is in a file, then Document document will be instantiated like this:

astNode.text: If your XML is in a file, then Document document will be instantiated like this:

node.contents: The document.getDocumentElement() returns you the node that is the document element of the document (in your case <config>).

astNode.text: The document.getDocumentElement() returns you the node that is the document element of the document (in your case <config>).

node.contents: Once you have a rootElement, you can access the element's attribute (by calling rootElement.getAttribute() method), etc. For more methods on java's org.w3c.dom.Element

astNode.text: Once you have a rootElement, you can access the element's attribute (by calling rootElement.getAttribute() method), etc. For more methods on java's org.w3c.dom.Element

node.contents: @BlaiseDoughan I added your suggestion to the answer. Thanks.

astNode.text: @BlaiseDoughan I added your suggestion to the answer. Thanks.

node.contents: +1 - But I would recommend calling the `evaluate` method that takes an `InputSource` instead. This gives the XPath implementation the chance to not build a DOM if it doesn't need one. This can lead to a performance improvement.

astNode.text: +1 - But I would recommend calling the `evaluate` method that takes an `InputSource` instead. This gives the XPath implementation the chance to not build a DOM if it doesn't need one. This can lead to a performance improvement.

node.contents: XPath is probably the way to go here.

astNode.text: XPath is probably the way to go here.

node.contents: I have put the xml file as a resource but you may have it in a file structure.

astNode.text: I have put the xml file as a resource but you may have it in a file structure.

elements.contents: DocumentBuilderFactory factory = DocumentBuilderFactory.newInstance(); DocumentBuilder builder = factory.newDocumentBuilder(); ClassLoader loader = XmlTestReader.class.getClassLoader(); InputStream is = loader.getResourceAsStream("test.xml"); Document doc = builder.parse(is);

units.rawText: DocumentBuilderFactory factory = DocumentBuilderFactory.newInstance(); DocumentBuilder builder = factory.newDocumentBuilder(); ClassLoader loader = XmlTestReader.class.getClassLoader(); InputStream is = loader.getResourceAsStream("test.xml"); Document doc = builder.parse(is);

node.contents: Then create an XPath expression.

astNode.text: Then create an XPath expression.

elements.contents: XPathFactory xPathFactory = XPathFactory.newInstance(); XPath xPath = xPathFactory.newXPath(); XPathExpression expr = xPath.compile("/Main/Port[@name='write_qwe']/output/return/@code"); NodeList nl = (NodeList) expr.evaluate(doc, XPathConstants.NODESET);

units.rawText: XPathFactory xPathFactory = XPathFactory.newInstance(); XPath xPath = xPathFactory.newXPath(); XPathExpression expr = xPath.compile("/Main/Port[@name='write_qwe']/output/return/@code"); NodeList nl = (NodeList) expr.evaluate(doc, XPathConstants.NODESET);

node.contents: The XPath expression /Main/Port[@name='write_qwe']/output/return/@code will find all code attributes where the Port's attribute name is write_qwe.

astNode.text: The XPath expression /Main/Port[@name='write_qwe']/output/return/@code will find all code attributes where the Port's attribute name is write_qwe.

node.contents: And now you can iterate over the nodes like this:

astNode.text: And now you can iterate over the nodes like this:

elements.contents: for (int i = 0; i < nl.getLength(); i++) { Node node = nl.item(i); System.out.println(node.getNodeValue()); }

units.rawText: for (int i = 0; i < nl.getLength(); i++) { Node node = nl.item(i); System.out.println(node.getNodeValue()); }

node.contents: You can restrict the XPath to /Main/Port[@name='write_qwe']/output/return if you want the whole <return> node instead.

astNode.text: You can restrict the XPath to /Main/Port[@name='write_qwe']/output/return if you want the whole <return> node instead.

node.contents: And iterating like this instead:

astNode.text: And iterating like this instead:

elements.contents: for (int i = 0; i < nl.getLength(); i++) { Node node = nl.item(i); System.out.println(node.getAttributes().getNamedItem("code").getNodeValue()); }

units.rawText: for (int i = 0; i < nl.getLength(); i++) { Node node = nl.item(i); System.out.println(node.getAttributes().getNamedItem("code").getNodeValue()); }

node.contents: Edit

astNode.text: Edit

node.contents: As suggested by the comment by Blaise Doughan it might be better to use an InputSource as input to XPathExpression#evaluate() instead:

astNode.text: As suggested by the comment by Blaise Doughan it might be better to use an InputSource as input to XPathExpression#evaluate() instead:

elements.contents: ClassLoader loader = XmlTestReader.class.getClassLoader(); InputStream inputStream = loader.getResourceAsStream("test.xml"); InputSource inputSource = new InputSource(inputStream); XPathFactory xPathFactory = XPathFactory.newInstance(); XPath xPath = xPathFactory.newXPath(); XPathExpression expr = xPath.compile("/Main/Port[@name='write_qwe']/output/return/@code"); NodeList nl = (NodeList) expr.evaluate(inputSource , XPathConstants.NODESET);

units.rawText: ClassLoader loader = XmlTestReader.class.getClassLoader(); InputStream inputStream = loader.getResourceAsStream("test.xml"); InputSource inputSource = new InputSource(inputStream); XPathFactory xPathFactory = XPathFactory.newInstance(); XPath xPath = xPathFactory.newXPath(); XPathExpression expr = xPath.compile("/Main/Port[@name='write_qwe']/output/return/@code"); NodeList nl = (NodeList) expr.evaluate(inputSource , XPathConstants.NODESET);
